DISMATH101: Solved Problems in Discrete Math Chapter 1 Logic 1.1 Propositional Logic 1.2 Logical connectives 1.3 Truth table 1.4 Logical Equivalences 1.5 Predicate Logic 1.6 Quantifiers 1.7 Rules of Inference

DISMATH101: Solved Problems in Discrete Math Melvin Cabatuan 2017-05-13 Chapter 1 Logic 1.1 Propositional Logic 1.2 Logical connectives 1.3 Truth table 1.4 Logical Equivalences 1.5 Predicate Logic 1.6 Quantifiers 1.7 Rules of Inference The following statements are propositions, EXCEPT: A. Euclid of Alexandria is human.\(\hspace{3cm}\:\)C. \(5 > 8\) B. \(1 + 1 = 2\) \(\hspace{6.4cm}\)D. Who am I? Definition 1.1 (Proposition) a statement that is either true or false (but not both). Solution: “D. Who am I?” is not a proposition because interrogative statements have no truth value. What is the question? Solution: “I thoroughly disapprove of duels. If a man should challenge me, I would take him kindly and forgivingly by the hand and lead him to a quiet place and kill him.”
